BioID offers its biometric authentication technology as a software development kit (SDK) for developers who want to integrate BioID capabilities into their applications. The SDK includes the following advanced biometric recognition techniques, which can be used alone or in combination: Fast and accurate face finding and robust face recognition (facial scan) even with low-cost, low-quality video hardware Speaker recognition using speech enhancement for increased robustness in adverse acoustic conditions Fusion of multiple biometric traits The BioID SDK facilitates rapid and flexible integration of some or all of these technologies within customer-specific applications. BioID's biometric authentication is the answer to higher security and higher convenience needs that cannot be met by traditional authentication methods such as PINs, passwords, or tokens. Therefore, BioID's technology provides an easier and more secure way to link real people with their digital identities, for a wide range of applications. BioID's solutions were designed with privacy in mind. Privacy of biometric information From the very beginning, BioID's technology was designed with privacy in mind. Our authentication solutions can be configured to match your application-specific legal requirements and your company's security policy. Your template contains only mathematical representations of your unique face, voice, and iris features. It does not contain any raw images or recordings, and cannot be used to reconstruct the raw images. Depending on the application, the encrypted template can be securely stored in different places: Locally on the device On a SIM card, smart card, or USB token With a trusted third party authentication service The type of information transmitted between your device and an external server depends on where the template is stored and where matching takes place, which varies for different applications. All information transmitted for authentication purposes is encrypted, so that only a system with the decryption key can read it. All information is also digitally signed, providing a time stamp, a way to detect tampering, and can bind the information to a legal identity if the digital signature is issued by a legal entity such as a government or authorized service provider. BioID's technology supports the BioAPI: the industry standard for The BioAPI Consortium has developed industry standards for biometric application interfaces. According to their specification, a biometric vendor may be called "BioAPI compatible" when he supports a certain subset of the functions specified. To use those BioAPI compliant functions, the vendor has to provide a so called "Biometric Service Provider" module, abbreviated BSP.
